title: 115_s2031
content: The "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act" authorizes the conveyance of certain Federal land in Louisiana for market value consideration. Key terms include Collins Camp Properties, Secretary of Agriculture, and State of Louisiana. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF CONVEYANCES, KISATCHIE NATIONAL FOREST, LOUISIANA. The Secretary is authorized to convey Federal land in Louisiana by quitclaim deed, including a 2.16-acre parcel in Winn Parish. The Secretary is authorized to convey Federal land in Louisiana, including a 2.16-acre parcel in Winn Parish, subject to certain conditions. During a 1-year period, the Secretary will convey approximately 47.92 acres of Federal land in Winn Parish, Louisiana to Collins Camp Properties upon payment, as depicted on a survey by Glen L. Cannon. The Secretary will convey Federal land in Winn Parish, Louisiana to Collins Camp Properties as depicted on a survey by Glen L. Cannon. The Secretary may configure the land to maximize marketability or achieve management objectives and establish terms and conditions for the conveyance. The Secretary may convey Federal land in Winn Parish, Louisiana to Collins Camp Properties to maximize marketability or achieve management objectives, with terms and conditions determined to be in the public interest. Consideration for the conveyance shall be in cash and equal to the market value of the land. The market value of the land shall be determined accordingly. The market value of Federal land conveyed under this Act shall be determined by an appraisal conducted in accordance with standards approved by the Secretary, or by competitive sale if conveyed by a different method. In any conveyance of Federal land under this Act, the Secretary must meet disclosure requirements for hazardous substances but is not obligated to remediate or abate them. This does not affect the application of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. In conveyances of Federal land under this Act, the Secretary must disclose hazardous substances but is not required to remediate or abate them. This does not impact the application of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. SEC. 5. PROCEEDS FROM THE SALE OF LAND. The Secretary will deposit proceeds from the sale of Federal land under section 4 into the fund established under Public Law 90-171 (16 U.S.C. 484a). SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATION. As a condition of conveyance of Federal land to Collins Camp Properties, the Secretary requires payment for appraisal costs and necessary administrative and environmental analyses. Collins Camp Properties must provide a written statement from each holder of a Forest Service special use authorization agreeing to relinquish their rights when making an offer for land acquisition. The acquisition of Federal land under section 4 requires holders of Forest Service special use authorizations to provide a written statement agreeing to relinquish their rights to Collins Camp Properties. If a holder fails to do so, Collins Camp Properties must administer the special use authorization as a condition of the conveyance. If a holder of a Forest Service special use authorization fails to provide a written authorization to relinquish their rights to Collins Camp Properties, the Secretary will require Collins Camp Properties to administer the special use authorization until it expires.
